goal_name: A healthy population that enjoys a high quality of physical, mental, spiritual and social well-being
target_name: Reduced the incidence of communicable and non-communicable diseases
GoalDescription: A healthy population that enjoys a high quality of physical, mental, spiritual and social well-being
PolicyObjectiveDescription: Reduced the incidence of communicable and non-communicable diseases
TargetDescription:
By 2020, the annual parasitic incidence rate (API) for all cases of malaria is no more than 1 per 1,000 population nationally 
By 2025, no more than 0.5 per 1,000 population
By 2030, no more than 0.5 per 1,000 population
By 2025, no more than 0.5 per 1,000 population
By 2030, no more than 0.5 per 1,000 population
Definition: Incidence of malaria is defined as the number of new cases of malaria per 1,000 people at risk each year.
Concept: Case of malaria is defined as the occurrence of malaria infection in a person whom the presence of malaria parasites in the blood has been confirmed by a diagnostic test. The population considered is the population at risk of the disease.
Rationale: To measure trends in malaria morbidity and to identify locations where the risk of disease is highest. With this information, programmes can respond to unusual trends, such as epidemics, and direct resources to the populations most in need. This data also serves to inform global resource allocation for malaria such as when defining eligibility criteria for Global Fund finance.
ComputationMethod: (number of Malaria annual parasite) / (total pop) X 100
DataSource: Health Information System  (HIS) | Vanuatu Ministry of Health
source_organisation_1: 2015 Health Data, Malaria and Vector Borne Diseases Unit, MoH (from M&E Framework)
